prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 2
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous great detective, whose deductions never fail to surprise.
Character 3
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 4
Name: Odie Asman
Description: The man who perished in the explosion on the experimentation stage at the Great Exhibition of London.↳The man who perished in the explosion on the experimentation stage. He was Professor Harebrayne's financial backer and the boss of a large criminal organisation.
Character 5
Name: Albert Harebrayne
Description: A scientist who invented a machine to demonstrate super-high-voltage instantaneous kinesis. However, it exploded in use, and he is now accused of murder.↳A scientist who invented a machine to demonstrate super-high-voltage instantaneous kinesis. He's the defendant of this case and a friend to Lord van Zieks, apparently.
Character 6
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Supposedly, the souls of those he prosecutes are eternally damned, one way or another.
Character 7
Name: Masked Man
Description: An apprentice of Lord van Zieks whose face is always covered by a mask. He has the air of a completely unassailable man.
Character 8
Name: Gina Lestrade
Description: A mostly reformed pickpocket who's now a self-appointed 'detective inspector'. She's really making waves in her new apprenticeship.
Character 9
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: The detective inspector in charge of Scotland Yard's investigation of the case. He's stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 10
Name: Esmeralda Tusspells
Description: The proprietress of the Madame Tusspells Museum of Waxwork and the latest in a line of artisans privy to the secret Tusspells technique of capturing a perfect likeness.
Character 11
Name: Balthazar Lune
Description: The impresario of short pleasure voyages in flying balloons. The balloons above the experimentation state all belonged to this man.
Character 12
Name: Bohemian Boy
Description: A young boy who came to London to visit the Great Exhibition. His real name is Wilhelm Gottsreich Sigismond Ormstein.↳A young prince from the royal family of Bohemia with an excessively long name. He witnessed the explosion at the Great Exhibition.
Character 13
Name: Courtney Sithe
Description: Scotland Yard coroner, leader of the Forensic Investigation Team and one of Lord Stronghart's most trusted allies.
Character 14
Name: Enoch Drebber
Description: A trickster who seems to be both an engineer and a magician. He constructed the machine for Professor Harebrayne's demonstration.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Great Exhibition Newspaper
Description: A newspaper containing various articles about the world-leading science and technology on show at the Great Exhibition being held in London.
Evidence 2
Name: Experiment Sketch
Description: A diagram showing the relative positions of the Crystal Tower and Professor Harebrayne's machine that exploded.
Evidence 3
Name: Mysterious Contraption → Crossbow
Description: A very curious device found behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds, almost as if it had been hidden there deliberately. A weapon found hidden behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. It turns out that it's a folding crossbow. A crossbow found hidden behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. It belongs to Mr Enoch Drebber.
Evidence 4
Name: Piece of Green Cloth
Description: A torn piece of canvas-like material backed with rubber that was found under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. There are scorch marks at the edges.
Evidence 5
Name: Photograph of the Victim
Description: A photographic print of the victim taken after he had ostensibly been 'beamed' to the Crystal Tower. It shows an apparent stab wound to the chest.
Evidence 6
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the victim, Mr Asman. His neck was broken from the impact of a violent fall and he was stabbed in the chest with a sharp object.
Evidence 7
Name: Screwdriver
Description: Professor Harebrayne's trusty screwdriver that he's named 'Andrew'. There are traces of blood at the tip and it matches the shape of the victim's wound. A metal screwdriver that was found poking through the grille in the base of what remains of the kinesis machine. It has a very distinctive handle.
Evidence 8
Name: Photograph of the Balloon
Description: A photograph taken by Gotts whilst he was riding in a balloon. It shows another balloon that he claims was green and exploded moments after he took this shot.
Evidence 9
Name: Drebber's Card
Description: Mr Enoch Drebber's business card, though it shows only the man's name. There is no address. Mr Enoch Drebber's business card, which lists no address for the man. There is a smear of machine oil on the reverse.
Evidence 10
Name: Wooden 'Birdcage'
Description: The wooden cage that was used for Professor Harebrayne's experiment. This cage, with the victim inside, crashed down into the Crystal Tower. The wooden cage that was used for the demonstration. It crashed down, with the victim inside, into the Crystal Tower causing damage to its base.
Evidence 11
Name: Photograph of Drebber
Description: A photographic print of the engineer, Mr Enoch Drebber. It's hard to make out, but he appears to be wearing a monocle with black glass.
Evidence 12
Name: Camera
Description: The camera from around the neck of a waxwork in the Madame Tusspells Special Exhibit. The actual camera that Mr Drebber had with him ten years ago when he went graverobbing. The actual camera that Mr Drebber had with him ten years ago when he went graverobbing. When the lens is extended, dark staining can be seen on the bellows.
Evidence 13
Name: Piece of Broken Glass
Description: A small fragment of very unusual and thick glass that was found in the folds of the clothing of the Professor waxwork. It would appear to be from the Crystal Tower.
Evidence 14
Name: Science Trophy
Description: A Royal Society trophy for excellence in science that was found in Mr Drebber's workshop. It's a very prestigious award for a young scientist.
Evidence 15
Name: Waxwork Head
Description: The head of the Professor waxwork that was stolen from the Madame Tusspells Special Exhibit.
Evidence 16
Name: Killer's Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the mass murderer known as the Professor, who was tried and found guilty by closed trial ten years ago.
Evidence 17
Name: Post-Explosion Photograph
Description: A photographic print of the experimentation stage after it was completely levelled by a time bomb. The metal floor of the stage has been blown open by the explosion.
Evidence 18
Name: Drebber's Contract
Description: The contract between Mr Asman and Mr Drebber detailing the terms by which they would profit from the kinesis experiment.
Evidence 19
Name: Ten-Year-Old Article
Description: A newspaper article recounting the tale of an eyewitness to the alleged 'resurrection' of the Professor from his grave on the night of his execution.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: The corpse that went crashin' through the Crystal Tower had a broken neck.
Person: Gregson
Testimony 1
Testimony: I, I made a minor miscalculation in the angle of the beam projection, that's all! That was my mistake!
Person: Harebrayne
Testimony 2
Testimony: But the post-mortem examination revealed another injury. A fatal wound.
Person: Gregson
Testimony 3
Testimony: There was a lesion in his chest where he'd clearly been stabbed by somethin' sharp right in the heart!
Person: Gregson
Testimony 4
Testimony: So the victim was killed before he went anywhere. And this fella's the only one who could have done it!
Person: Gregson
Testimony 5
Testimony: The weapon the victim was stabbed with must have been left in his body whilst he was beamed through the air!
Person: Gregson

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's tackle this problem step by step. I need to find a pair of evidence and testimony that contradict each other. Let me start by going through each evidence and testimony provided.

First, looking at the evidences:

Evidence 6: Autopsy Report states that the victim (Drebber?) had a neck broken from impact and a stab wound in the chest. 

Evidence 7: Screwdriver found in the machine has blood traces and matches the wound shape. So the screwdriver is the possible murder weapon, left at the scene. 

Now the testimonies from Gregson:

Testimony 0: The corpse had a broken neck from the fall into the Crystal Tower. 

Testimony 2: Post-mortem showed another injury, a fatal stab wound. 

Testimony 3: The victim was stabbed in the heart before being beamed. 

Testimony 4: Gregson says the defendant (Harebrayne?) is the only one who could have done it. 

Testimony 5: The weapon must have been left in the body during the beam. 

Wait, Testimony 5 says the weapon was left in the body during the beaming. But Evidence 7 says the screwdriver was found in the machine, not in the body. If the testimony claims the weapon was left in the victim's chest, but the evidence shows it was found elsewhere, that's a contradiction.

So Testimony 5 says the weapon was left in the body, but Evidence 7 shows the screwdriver (the weapon) was found in the machine, not in the victim. Therefore, those two contradict each other.

Alternatively, check other possibilities. Let me confirm:

Testimony 5: "The weapon the victim was stabbed with must have been left in his body whilst he was beamed through the air!" 

Evidence 7 says the screwdriver was found poking through the grille in the machine's base, not in the victim's body. So if the testimony claims the weapon was in the body during beaming, but the evidence shows it wasn't (since it's found elsewhere), that's a contradiction between Evidence 7 and Testimony 5.

Hence the pair is Evidence 7 and Testimony 5.
</think>

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's tackle this problem step by step. I need to find a pair of evidence and testimony that contradict each other. Let me start by going through each piece of evidence and testimony provided.

First, looking at the characters, the main ones involved here are Professor Harebrayne, who's the defendant, and Odie Asman, the victim. The evidence includes items like the screwdriver (Evidence 7) which has traces of blood matching the victim's wound. The autopsy report (Evidence 6) mentions that Asman was stabbed with a sharp object, which aligns with the screwdriver's description.

Now, the testimonies from Harebrayne (Testimonies 0-4) are all from the defendant. In Testimony 1, Harebrayne states that his hypothesis says the kinesis can't transport metal, so a metal weapon would stay behind. This is important because if the screwdriver (Evidence 7) was the weapon used, and it's made of metal, then according to his testimony, it couldn't have been transported. However, the autopsy shows the victim was stabbed, implying the weapon was present during the attack. But the screwdriver was found at the scene (in the machine's base), which might mean it was left behind as Harebrayne said. Wait, but if the stabbing happened during the beam transport, then the weapon should have stayed, but the victim was found with the wound. So maybe the contradiction is here?

Wait, Testimony 5 from Gregson (not listed here, but in the previous problem's testimonies) might be different, but in this current set, Harebrayne's Testimony 1 says the metal weapon wouldn't be transported. The screwdriver is metal and matches the wound. If the stabbing happened before the beam, then the weapon would remain, but the wound would still be there. But the testimony might imply that the weapon wasn't on the victim, so how did the wound happen? Wait, the autopsy says the victim was stabbed, and the screwdriver was found at the scene. If Harebrayne's theory is correct, then the weapon couldn't have been transported, so the stabbing must have happened after the transport? Or before? This is getting a bit tangled.

Alternatively, maybe the contradiction is between Evidence 7 (the screwdriver matching the wound) and Harebrayne's Testimony 1. If the screwdriver is the weapon, and it's metal, then according to his own testimony, it couldn't have been transported with Asman. So if Asman was stabbed with it, the stabbing must have happened before the kinesis beam, and the screwdriver was left behind. But the autopsy shows the wound was present after the transport. So that would mean the stabbing happened before the beam, and the weapon was left, but the wound is still there. That's possible. Hmm, maybe not a contradiction here.

Wait, looking again at Testimony 5 from Gregson (from the previous problem's testimonies) said the weapon must have been left in the body, but here in the current problem, Harebrayne's Testimony 1 says metal can't be transported. If the screwdriver (metal) was the weapon, then it couldn't have been transported, so the stabbing must have happened before the beam. But the wound would still be present, so maybe that's okay. Maybe I need to look elsewhere.

Another evidence is Evidence 3, the crossbow belonging to Drebber. But that's maybe not related. Evidence 18 is the contract between Asman and Drebber, implying their partnership. Harebrayne's Testimony 3 says Asman was his patron, so that's consistent with the contract.

Wait, maybe the contradiction is between Evidence 7 (screwdriver matching the wound) and Harebrayne's Testimony 1. If the screwdriver is the weapon, then according to his testimony, it couldn't have been transported. So the stabbing had to happen before the beam. But the autopsy shows the victim had the wound, which would be consistent. However, if the screwdriver was found at the scene (the machine's base), then it's possible that the stabbing occurred there before the beam, so the wound is there. That seems consistent. Maybe not a contradiction.

Wait, Testimony 2 from Harebrayne says "the point just raised by Mr Naruhodo isn't an inconsistency at all." This might refer to a prior argument, but without context, it's hard to tell. Alternatively, maybe the contradiction is between the autopsy report (Evidence 6) stating the victim was stabbed with a sharp object, and the screwdriver (Evidence 7) being the weapon, but Harebrayne's testimony that he didn't do it? Wait, no, Harebrayne isn't directly denying it, but Testimony 1's point is about the metal not being transported. 

Alternatively, maybe the contradiction is between Evidence 18 (the contract between Asman and Drebber) and Harebrayne's Testimony 3, which says Asman was his patron. If the contract is between Asman and Drebber, that might indicate Drebber was involved, but Harebrayne's testimony says Asman was his patron, so maybe that's okay. Not a contradiction.

Hmm, perhaps I'm missing something. Let me recheck all evidence and testimonies again.

Looking at Testimony 1: "My hypothesis states the kinesis cannot transport metal, though. Hence the metal weapon would have stayed put." So if the stabbing weapon was metal (like the screwdriver), then it would stay behind. But the autopsy shows the victim was stabbed, so the weapon must have been present when the stabbing happened. If the stabbing happened during the beam transport, then the weapon couldn't have been transported, so the stabbing must have occurred before the beam, leaving the weapon behind. The screwdriver was found at the scene (in the machine's base), so that's consistent. Therefore, there's no contradiction here. 

Wait, but Testimony 5 (from Gregson in the previous problem) said the weapon was left in the body, but that's not in the current testimonies. Here, in current testimonies, Harebrayne is saying the metal can't be transported, so the weapon wouldn't be there. But the wound is there, so the stabbing had to happen before the beam. That's possible. Maybe no contradiction here.

Another angle: Evidence 3 is a crossbow belonging to Drebber. If the crossbow was the weapon, then that's different from the screwdriver. But the screwdriver matches the wound. So if Drebber's crossbow was the weapon, but the screwdriver is found, that's conflicting. But the crossbow is a different weapon. However, the testimony from Harebrayne doesn't mention Drebber's crossbow. Maybe not.

Alternatively, maybe the contradiction is between Harebrayne's Testimony 1 and the fact that the screwdriver was found at the scene (Evidence 7). If the screwdriver was the weapon, then according to his testimony, it couldn't have been transported, so the stabbing must have happened before the beam. But the autopsy shows the victim was stabbed, so that's okay. Not a contradiction.

Wait, maybe the contradiction is between Testimony 1 and the screwdriver's presence. If the screwdriver was used to stab Asman before the beam, then it would be left behind. But the screwdriver was found in the machine's base, which is part of the experiment setup. So that's consistent. 

Hmm, maybe I need to look at another evidence. Let me check Evidence 5, the photo of the victim showing a stab wound. If the stabbing happened before the beam, then the wound would be visible in the photo. The photo (Evidence 5) does show the wound, so that's consistent with the autopsy. 

Alternatively, perhaps the contradiction is between Harebrayne's Testimony 1 and the fact that the screwdriver was found at the scene. Since he says metal can't be transported, so the weapon (screwdriver) was left behind, which is exactly where it was found. So no contradiction there.

Wait, maybe I'm overcomplicating. Let me see the possible pairs again. The user wants one pair. Maybe between Evidence 7 (screwdriver matches wound) and Harebrayne's Testimony 1 (metal weapon stays, so if he used it, it would be there, but he's the professor, so maybe he's being accused of using it, but his testimony says he didn't intend to harm). Wait, but Testimony 1 is about the kinesis, not about him using the weapon. 

Alternatively, maybe the contradiction is between Evidence 6 (autopsy says stabbed with sharp object) and Testimony 1's implication that the weapon couldn't have been transported, so the stabbing must have been before, but if the victim was transported, then how did the wound get there? Wait, no, because if stabbed before, then the wound would exist when transported. So that's okay.

Hmm, perhaps I need to consider other evidence. Let's look at Evidence 3, the crossbow belonging to Drebber. If the crossbow was the weapon, then the stab wound might be from an arrow, but the screwdriver's shape matches the wound. So maybe the crossbow's arrow isn't the weapon, contradicting Evidence 3 and Evidence 7. But that's between evidences, not evidence and testimony.

Alternatively, maybe the contract (Evidence 18) between Asman and Drebber contradicts Harebrayne's Testimony 3 that Asman was his patron. If Asman was working with Drebber, maybe Harebrayne's claim is a lie. But that's more of a character contradiction than evidence vs testimony.

Wait, looking back, maybe I missed something in the current testimonies. The user provided the current testimonies as:

Testimony 0: Harebrayne says he's still gathering data.
Testimony 1: His hypothesis says kinesis can't transport metal, so the weapon stays.
Testimony 2: Naruhodo's point isn't inconsistent.
Testimony 3: Asman was his patron.
Testimony 4: He must protect the machine they built.

So the key point is Testimony 1 about metal not being transported. If the screwdriver (metal) was the weapon, then it couldn't have been transported with Asman. Therefore, the stabbing must have occurred before the beam, leaving the weapon behind. The screwdriver was found at the scene (Evidence 7), so that's consistent. Thus, no contradiction here.

Wait a minute. The autopsy says the victim was stabbed (Evidence 6). If the stabbing happened before the beam, then the wound would be present when Asman was transported. That's okay. But Testimony 5 from Gregson (previous problem) said the weapon was left in the body. But in current problem's evidence, the screwdriver is found at the scene, not in the body. So if Gregson's testimony (from previous) says the weapon was left in the body, but the screwdriver is found elsewhere, that's a contradiction. But in this current problem's setup, Gregson's testimonies aren't listed here. The user is asking about the current provided testimonies and evidences.

Looking again, maybe Evidence 18 (contract between Asman and Drebber) contradicts Harebrayne's Testimony 3 that Asman was his patron. If Asman was working with Drebber, maybe he wasn't Harebrayne's patron. But that's not a direct contradiction; they could have multiple patrons. 

Alternatively, Evidence 3's crossbow (Drebber's) might be the murder weapon, but Evidence 7's screwdriver matches the wound, so they can't both be true. But that's between evidences, not with a testimony.

Hmm, maybe I'm missing something. Let's see:

Harebrayne's Testimony 1 says metal can't be transported. The screwdriver is metal and matches the wound. So if the stabbing happened during the transport, the weapon would have stayed behind. But the wound would still exist. The autopsy shows the wound, so that's okay. The screwdriver being found at the scene is consistent with it being left behind. Therefore, no contradiction.

Wait, but if the stabbing happened before the beam, then the stabbing location is where the machine is. So the victim was stabbed there, then beamed. That makes sense. So no contradiction here.

Hmm, maybe I'm overthinking. Let me think of another angle. 

Testimony 2 says that Naruhodo's point isn't an inconsistency. So maybe Naruhodo pointed out a contradiction, but Harebrayne is denying it. The user is asking us to find the actual contradiction. 

Perhaps the contradiction is between Evidence 7 (the screwdriver was found in the machine's base) and Harebrayne's Testimony 1. If the screwdriver was the murder weapon, and it was found in the machine's base (where the experiment was), that would mean the stabbing happened there before the beam. But the autopsy shows the victim was stabbed, so that's okay. Not a contradiction.

Alternatively, maybe the crossbow (Evidence 3) is the weapon, but the screwdriver matches the wound. So the crossbow's arrow would have a different wound, contradicting Evidence 7's screwdriver match. But that's between evidences.

Wait, perhaps the correct pair is Evidence 7 and Testimony 1. Because if the screwdriver was used to stab, and it's metal, then according to Testimony 1, it couldn't have been transported, so the stabbing had to be before the beam. But the screwdriver was found at the scene, which is where the beam started, so that's consistent. No contradiction there.

prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 2
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous great detective, whose deductions never fail to surprise.
Character 3
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 4
Name: Odie Asman
Description: The man who perished in the explosion on the experimentation stage at the Great Exhibition of London.↳The man who perished in the explosion on the experimentation stage. He was Professor Harebrayne's financial backer and the boss of a large criminal organisation.
Character 5
Name: Albert Harebrayne
Description: A scientist who invented a machine to demonstrate super-high-voltage instantaneous kinesis. However, it exploded in use, and he is now accused of murder.↳A scientist who invented a machine to demonstrate super-high-voltage instantaneous kinesis. He's the defendant of this case and a friend to Lord van Zieks, apparently.
Character 6
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Supposedly, the souls of those he prosecutes are eternally damned, one way or another.
Character 7
Name: Masked Man
Description: An apprentice of Lord van Zieks whose face is always covered by a mask. He has the air of a completely unassailable man.
Character 8
Name: Gina Lestrade
Description: A mostly reformed pickpocket who's now a self-appointed 'detective inspector'. She's really making waves in her new apprenticeship.
Character 9
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: The detective inspector in charge of Scotland Yard's investigation of the case. He's stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 10
Name: Esmeralda Tusspells
Description: The proprietress of the Madame Tusspells Museum of Waxwork and the latest in a line of artisans privy to the secret Tusspells technique of capturing a perfect likeness.
Character 11
Name: Balthazar Lune
Description: The impresario of short pleasure voyages in flying balloons. The balloons above the experimentation state all belonged to this man.
Character 12
Name: Bohemian Boy
Description: A young boy who came to London to visit the Great Exhibition. His real name is Wilhelm Gottsreich Sigismond Ormstein.↳A young prince from the royal family of Bohemia with an excessively long name. He witnessed the explosion at the Great Exhibition.
Character 13
Name: Courtney Sithe
Description: Scotland Yard coroner, leader of the Forensic Investigation Team and one of Lord Stronghart's most trusted allies.
Character 14
Name: Enoch Drebber
Description: A trickster who seems to be both an engineer and a magician. He constructed the machine for Professor Harebrayne's demonstration.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Great Exhibition Newspaper
Description: A newspaper containing various articles about the world-leading science and technology on show at the Great Exhibition being held in London.
Evidence 2
Name: Experiment Sketch
Description: A diagram showing the relative positions of the Crystal Tower and Professor Harebrayne's machine that exploded.
Evidence 3
Name: Mysterious Contraption → Crossbow
Description: A very curious device found behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds, almost as if it had been hidden there deliberately. A weapon found hidden behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. It turns out that it's a folding crossbow. A crossbow found hidden behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. It belongs to Mr Enoch Drebber.
Evidence 4
Name: Piece of Green Cloth
Description: A torn piece of canvas-like material backed with rubber that was found under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. There are scorch marks at the edges.
Evidence 5
Name: Photograph of the Victim
Description: A photographic print of the victim taken after he had ostensibly been 'beamed' to the Crystal Tower. It shows an apparent stab wound to the chest.
Evidence 6
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the victim, Mr Asman. His neck was broken from the impact of a violent fall and he was stabbed in the chest with a sharp object.
Evidence 7
Name: Screwdriver
Description: Professor Harebrayne's trusty screwdriver that he's named 'Andrew'. There are traces of blood at the tip and it matches the shape of the victim's wound. A metal screwdriver that was found poking through the grille in the base of what remains of the kinesis machine. It has a very distinctive handle.
Evidence 8
Name: Photograph of the Balloon
Description: A photograph taken by Gotts whilst he was riding in a balloon. It shows another balloon that he claims was green and exploded moments after he took this shot.
Evidence 9
Name: Drebber's Card
Description: Mr Enoch Drebber's business card, though it shows only the man's name. There is no address. Mr Enoch Drebber's business card, which lists no address for the man. There is a smear of machine oil on the reverse.
Evidence 10
Name: Wooden 'Birdcage'
Description: The wooden cage that was used for Professor Harebrayne's experiment. This cage, with the victim inside, crashed down into the Crystal Tower. The wooden cage that was used for the demonstration. It crashed down, with the victim inside, into the Crystal Tower causing damage to its base.
Evidence 11
Name: Photograph of Drebber
Description: A photographic print of the engineer, Mr Enoch Drebber. It's hard to make out, but he appears to be wearing a monocle with black glass.
Evidence 12
Name: Camera
Description: The camera from around the neck of a waxwork in the Madame Tusspells Special Exhibit. The actual camera that Mr Drebber had with him ten years ago when he went graverobbing. The actual camera that Mr Drebber had with him ten years ago when he went graverobbing. When the lens is extended, dark staining can be seen on the bellows.
Evidence 13
Name: Piece of Broken Glass
Description: A small fragment of very unusual and thick glass that was found in the folds of the clothing of the Professor waxwork. It would appear to be from the Crystal Tower.
Evidence 14
Name: Science Trophy
Description: A Royal Society trophy for excellence in science that was found in Mr Drebber's workshop. It's a very prestigious award for a young scientist.
Evidence 15
Name: Waxwork Head
Description: The head of the Professor waxwork that was stolen from the Madame Tusspells Special Exhibit.
Evidence 16
Name: Killer's Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the mass murderer known as the Professor, who was tried and found guilty by closed trial ten years ago.
Evidence 17
Name: Post-Explosion Photograph
Description: A photographic print of the experimentation stage after it was completely levelled by a time bomb. The metal floor of the stage has been blown open by the explosion.
Evidence 18
Name: Drebber's Contract
Description: The contract between Mr Asman and Mr Drebber detailing the terms by which they would profit from the kinesis experiment.
Evidence 19
Name: Ten-Year-Old Article
Description: A newspaper article recounting the tale of an eyewitness to the alleged 'resurrection' of the Professor from his grave on the night of his execution.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: It was an incidente terribile. I am only grateful that my balloons were not damaged.
Person: Lune
Testimony 1
Testimony: There's this huge bang from the stage, and then the next second, another bang in the sky beside us.
Person: Gina
Testimony 2
Testimony: And from amid ze smoke...a cage appeared out of nowhere!
Person: Gotts
Testimony 3
Testimony: It voz not ze sky zat exploded. It voz a green balloon zat woz next to ours at ze time.
Person: Gotts
Testimony 4
Testimony: The cage, it fell from the sky like a stone. And crashed into the Crystal Tower!
Person: Lune
Testimony 5
Testimony: I didn't get a good look inside the cage, but no one went near it after it crashed into the tower.
Person: Gina

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's tackle this problem step by step. I need to find a pair of evidence and testimony that contradict each other. Let's start by going through each evidence and testimony one by one to see where there might be inconsistencies.

First, looking at the characters and the case context: The victim, Odie Asman, died in an explosion at the Great Exhibition. The key here is that there's a machine involved in the experiment, and there are conflicting testimonies about what caused the explosion and the circumstances of the death.

Let me list out the evidences again to see which ones might conflict with the testimonies:

Evidence 3: A crossbow found under the experimentation stage belonging to Enoch Drebber. This could imply Drebber was involved in some way, maybe the stabbing mentioned in the autopsy.

Evidence 4: A piece of green cloth with scorch marks. The green color might relate to the green balloon mentioned by Gotts (Testimony 3).

Evidence 5: A photo of the victim showing a stab wound. The autopsy (Evidence 6) confirms the stab and broken neck from the fall.

Evidence 7: Harebrayne's screwdriver found in the machine, matching the stab wound. This suggests Harebrayne might have stabbed Asman before the experiment.

Evidence 8: A photo showing a green balloon that exploded. This aligns with Gotts' testimony (Testimony 3) about a green balloon exploding.

Evidence 10: The wooden cage (birdcage) that crashed into the Crystal Tower. Testimonies from Lune and Gotts mention the cage falling.

Evidence 17: Post-explosion photo showing the stage's floor blown open by a time bomb. This might conflict with the idea that the explosion was from the balloon or the machine.

Now the testimonies:

Testimony 0 (Lune): Mentions the incident was terrible, grateful his balloons weren't damaged. But if the green balloon was his, that might conflict.

Testimony 1 (Gina): Two bangs, then a cage appeared. The first explosion from the stage, then another in the sky (maybe the balloon).

Testimony 2 (Gotts): The cage appeared from smoke, implying it came from the explosion.

Testimony 3 (Gotts): The explosion was from a green balloon, not the sky. So the second explosion was the balloon.

Testimony 4 (Lune): The cage fell into the tower. Evidence 10 says the cage crashed into the tower, so that aligns.

Testimony 5 (Gina): No one went near the cage after it crashed. Not sure about contradiction here.

Looking at Evidence 17: The post-explosion photo shows the stage was levelled by a time bomb. If that's true, then the initial explosion was a time bomb under the stage, not the machine or the balloon. But Testimony 1 mentions the first explosion was from the stage, which could be the time bomb. However, Gotts says the second explosion was the green balloon. 

Wait, the key point is whether the primary explosion was from the machine (as per Harebrayne's experiment) or a time bomb (Evidence 17). If Evidence 17 shows the stage was destroyed by a time bomb, then the explosion wasn't due to the kinesis machine failing but a bomb. That would contradict any testimony that attributes the explosion to the machine's malfunction.

Looking at Testimony 1: Gina says the first explosion was from the stage (the experiment's machine), then another in the sky (the balloon). But Evidence 17 suggests the stage's destruction was from a time bomb. So if the stage's explosion was a bomb, then the initial explosion's cause is different. That would conflict with Testimony 1's account of the first explosion being from the experiment's machine.

Alternatively, Testimony 3 by Gotts says the explosion was from the green balloon, not the sky. Wait, he says "It voz not ze sky zat exploded. It voz a green balloon zat woz next to ours at ze time." So Gotts is clarifying that the explosion was from the balloon, not the sky itself. But Evidence 8's photo shows the green balloon exploding, which matches his testimony. However, Evidence 17's photo shows the stage was blown open by a time bomb, which might be a separate explosion.

Wait, maybe the contradiction is between Evidence 17 (time bomb caused the stage explosion) and Testimony 1 (first explosion was from the stage's experiment). If the stage's explosion was due to a time bomb, then it's not Harebrayne's machine failing but sabotage. Therefore, Testimony 1's account that the first explosion was from the stage (the experiment) would be contradicted by Evidence 17 showing it was a bomb.

Alternatively, maybe the two explosions (machine and balloon) both happened, but the Evidence 17's time bomb is a third factor. Hmm, need to check the details again.

Alternatively, looking at Evidence 8: the photo of the balloon shows the green balloon exploding, which aligns with Gotts' testimony. Evidence 17's time bomb might be the cause of the stage's destruction, separate from the balloon explosion. But maybe the main issue is whether the primary cause of Asman's death was the stab (from the screwdriver in Evidence 7) or the fall (autopsy mentions both neck break and stab). The testimonies about the explosions might not directly conflict unless the cause of the explosion is attributed to different sources.

Wait, the user wants only one pair. Let's see another angle. 

Evidence 3 is a crossbow belonging to Drebber found at the scene. The autopsy (Evidence 6) says the victim was stabbed. If the stab was done with the crossbow, then the screwdriver (Evidence 7) might not be the weapon. But the screwdriver's description says it matches the wound. So if the crossbow was the weapon, that would contradict Evidence 7. But the crossbow is a different weapon. Wait, crossbows shoot bolts, which are arrows, so the stab wound would be from a bolt. But the screwdriver is a different weapon. So if the autopsy says the stab was from a sharp object like a screwdriver, but the crossbow's bolt would leave a different wound, maybe there's a contradiction here. But the evidence says the screwdriver was found in the machine and matches the wound, so maybe that's the actual weapon, making the crossbow irrelevant. However, the crossbow's presence might suggest Drebber was involved in an attempted stabbing but didn't use it, instead the screwdriver was used. Not sure if that's a contradiction or just different evidence.

Alternatively, looking at Evidence 18 (Drebber's contract with Asman). If Harebrayne's testimony (Testimony 3) says Asman was his patron, but the contract shows Drebber had a deal with Asman, that might imply Asman was dealing with both, but not necessarily a contradiction. Unless the contract suggests Asman was working against Harebrayne, but the testimony says Harebrayne was loyal. Hmm, maybe that's a point.

Wait, Testimony 3 from Harebrayne says "Mr Asman was the patron of my research. Without him, my work wouldn't have been possible." But Evidence 18's contract is between Asman and Drebber. If Drebber was also involved with Asman, perhaps there's a conflict of interest, but not a direct contradiction unless the contract shows Asman was betraying Harebrayne, but that's not clear. Maybe not the strongest contradiction.

Back to the explosion causes. Evidence 17 says the stage was blown by a time bomb. If that's true, then the initial explosion (Testimony 1's first explosion from the stage) was the bomb, not the machine. So Harebrayne's experiment wasn't the cause. But Harebrayne is being accused of murder via the machine. If the explosion was a bomb, then maybe someone else set it. 

The contradiction would be between Evidence 17 (time bomb caused the stage explosion) and any testimony that attributes the stage's explosion to the machine's failure. For example, Testimony 1 says the first explosion was from the stage (the experiment's machine), but Evidence 17 shows it was a bomb. That's a contradiction.

So, Evidence 17 and Testimony 1 would be contradictory. Because Testimony 1 says the first explosion was from the stage's experiment (machine), while Evidence 17 says the stage was destroyed by a time bomb, implying the explosion was from the bomb, not the machine.

Therefore, the pair would be Evidence 17 and Testimony 1.
</think>

cot:
Okay, let me try to work through this problem step by step. The user has provided a list of characters, evidences, and testimonies, and they want to know which evidence and testimony contradict each other. I need to find one pair where an evidence and a testimony directly contradict each other.

First, I'll start by reviewing the testimonies provided. The testimonies here are from Testimony 0 to Testimony 4. Let me go through each testimony and see what they say.

Testimony 0: Balthazar Lune says that all his balloons landed safely because he's no liar. He's defending his balloons from being involved in any explosion.

Testimony 1: Lune again mentions that all three of his balloons were carrying passengers and if they had exploded, it would have been a catastrophe. This reinforces his claim that his balloons didn't explode.

Testimony 2: Gina says that a burnt piece of cloth was found at the scene, and the police think it's debris from the stage explosion.

Testimony 3: Gina adds that the police believe the cloth was debris from the stage explosion, not from a balloon.

Testimony 4: Lune says the boy (Gotts) is mistaken because his balloons have red and blue stripes, not green. This contradicts Gotts' earlier testimony about a green balloon exploding.

Now, looking at the evidences, especially Evidence 4: "Piece of Green Cloth" which is a torn piece of canvas-like material with scorch marks. The description mentions it was found under the experimentation stage. 

The key here is that Lune (Testimony 4) denies that any of his balloons were green, stating they have red and blue stripes. However, Evidence 4 is a piece of green cloth found at the scene. If the cloth is from a balloon, and it's green, that directly contradicts Lune's testimony that his balloons weren't green. 

Another point is Testimony 3 by Gina where the police think the cloth is from the stage explosion. But the contradiction here is between Lune's denial of a green balloon and the existence of green cloth evidence. The green cloth could be part of a balloon that exploded, which Lune denies being his. 

Therefore, the contradiction is between Evidence 4 (green cloth) and Testimony 4 (Lune's denial of a green balloon). The green cloth suggests there was a green balloon involved, which Lune claims didn't exist among his balloons.
